core_claim: When a honey bee stings a mammal, it releases a pheromone that marks the target for attack by other bees, and this alarm pheromone smells exactly like bananas.

supporting_details.concentration: Released at 1-2 nanograms per bee sting
supporting_details.detection: Detectable by other bees from up to 10 meters away
supporting_details.evolutionary_purpose: Coordinates colony defense against large predators

source_citation: Free, J.B. (1987). Pheromones of Social Bees. Chapman and Hall; Journal of Chemical Ecology, Vol. 8, No. 10, 1982
why_strange: The chemical that triggers bee attacks is identical to the compound that gives bananas their characteristic smell.

core_claim: A species of jellyfish, Turritopsis dohrnii, is biologically immortal, capable of reverting completely to its juvenile polyp stage after reaching sexual maturity through a process called transdifferentiation.

supporting_details.process: Can transform fully differentiated cells back into stem cells
supporting_details.limitation: Can still die from predation or disease

source_citation: Piraino, S., et al. (1996). Reversing the Life Cycle: Medusae Transforming into Polyps and Cell Transdifferentiation in Turritopsis nutricula. Biological Bulletin, 190(3), 302-312
why_strange: This organism can essentially reset its life cycle repeatedly, making it the only known animal with biological immortality.

core_claim: Quantum entanglement allows particles to instantaneously affect each other regardless of distance, a phenomenon Einstein called 'spooky action at a distance,' which was definitively proven in 2015 to occur faster than light speed.

supporting_details.speed: At least 10,000 times faster than light

source_citation: Hensen, B., et al. (2015). Loophole-free Bell inequality violation using electron spins separated by 1.3 kilometres. Nature, 526(7575), 682-686
why_strange: This phenomenon appears to violate Einstein's theory of relativity by allowing information to travel faster than light.

core_claim: The Mpemba effect is the counter-intuitive observation that hot water can freeze faster than cold water under identical conditions, first noted by Tanzanian student Erasto Mpemba in 1963.

supporting_details.discoverer: Erasto Mpemba, high school student making ice cream
supporting_details.temperature_difference: Hot water at 95°C can freeze before identical water at 18°C
supporting_details.proposed_mechanisms: Evaporation, dissolved gases, convection currents, supercooling

source_citation: Mpemba, E.B., Osborne, D.G. (1969). Cool? Physics Education, 4(3), 172-175; Royal Society of Chemistry Mpemba Effect competition, 2012
why_strange: It defies basic thermodynamic intuition that a hotter substance would reach freezing temperature before an identical colder one.

core_claim: Quantum entanglement has been shown to work over a distance of more than 1,200 kilometers, defying classical concepts of locality.

supporting_details.location: Between ground stations in Delingha, Lijiang, and Nanshan in China
supporting_details.participants: Chinese Academy of Sciences, led by physicist Jian-Wei Pan
supporting_details.method: Used the Micius satellite to distribute entangled photon pairs

source_citation: Yin, J. et al. (2017). 'Satellite-based entanglement distribution over 1200 kilometers.' Science, 356(6343), 1140–1144. DOI:10.1126/science.aan3211
why_strange: It suggests instantaneous quantum correlations over vast distances, seemingly violating the speed of light limit

core_claim: Tardigrades can survive in the vacuum of space and deadly radiation by entering a cryptobiotic state.

supporting_details.location: Low Earth orbit aboard the ESA's FOTON-M3 mission
supporting_details.participants: European Space Agency, researchers from Kristianstad University in Sweden
supporting_details.outcome: Many survived exposure to space vacuum and cosmic radiation

source_citation: Jönsson, K. I. et al. (2008). 'Tolerance to space conditions in the tardigrade Milnesium tardigradum.' Current Biology, 18(17), R729–R731. DOI:10.1016/j.cub.2008.06.048
why_strange: No other known animal can survive direct exposure to outer space without protection

core_claim: Bananas are naturally slightly radioactive due to their high potassium content, particularly the isotope potassium-40.

supporting_details.isotope: Potassium-40 (K-40), a naturally occurring radioactive isotope
supporting_details.comparison: Eating 100 bananas gives the same radiation dose as a single dental X-ray
supporting_details.concept: Used to illustrate radiation exposure in terms of the 'Banana Equivalent Dose'

source_citation: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA); Health Physics Society; Oak Ridge Associated Universities (ORAU)
why_strange: A common fruit is used as a unit of radiation measurement due to its natural radioactivity
